authorsByline: Joseph Rejent, Joseph Rejent | jrejent@njadvancemedia.com, jrejent
title: HBO Max is making a huge change next month. Here's what you need to know
description: HBO Max is making some big (and, frankly, annoying) changes next month. Here's everything you need to know.
content:
TV remote control is seen with HBO Max logo displayed on a screen in this illustration photo taken in Krakow, Poland on February 6, 2022. (Photo by Jakub Porzycki/NurPhoto via Getty Images) NurPhoto via Getty Images

We know, we know. You were probably just getting used to calling it HBO Max again.

But here comes the streaming world’s most tumultuous service with another huge change. This time, they’re coming for password sharing.

In a quarterly earnings call, JB Perrette, the head of streaming and gaming at Warner Bros. Discovery, announced that the company would be taking a more aggressive tack in dealing with password sharing. Perrette said the initiative would target “who’s a legitimate user who may not be a legitimate user.”

What this means is that the service will be monitoring information like device IDs and IP addresses to determine when an account is being shared outside the boundaries of one’s household. When the service uncovers instances of this, it will prompt those outside to pay an additional $7.99 per month to be added as an extra member.

Netflix kickstarted this crackdown trend back in 2023. Other services, like Disney Plus, have followed suit. With all of these massive corporations finding new ways to squeeze every dime out of consumers they possibly can, we find it’s best to bundle as many of these services together as possible.

The HBO Max/Disney Plus/Hulu bundle is perhaps the best example of this. For only $16.99 per month, you get all three services at a 42% savings.

HBO Max by itself is normally $16.99, so at least when you sign up for the bundle, you’re getting three services for the price of one. It doesn’t let you password share, but it does grant you access to thousands of hours of TV shows and movies at a pretty reasonable price.

We have no idea how long this bundle will last, so sign up now while you can.

Our journalism needs your support. Please subscribe today to NJ.com.

Joseph Rejent covers TV, writing about live television, streaming services and cord-cutting. He can be reached at jrejent@njadvancemedia.com.
summary: HBO Max is set to make a significant change in its user interface, focusing on password sharing. Warner Bros. Discovery, the head of streaming and gaming at the company, will monitor device IDs and IP addresses to identify accounts being shared outside of the home. This will require an additional $7.99 per month to be added as an extra member. The move follows a trend of companies like Netflix and Disney Plus leading to increased password sharing crackdowns. The HBO Max/Disney Plus/Hulu bundle offers a 42% savings for consumers, offering thousands of hours of TV shows and movies at a reasonable price.
shortSummary: HBO Max will introduce aggressive password sharing to combat fake accounts, prompting increased pricing and competition, while offering discounts in other services.

Karen may not want any company, but Tyler Perry’s “Sistas” will continue its 9th season with a 4th episode on BET on Wednesday, Aug. 6 at 9 p.m. The episode will be called “One is the Loneliest Number.” You can watch live as it premieres on Philo (free trial) or DirecTV (free trial) or Fubo TV (free trial).
In “One is the Loneliest Number,” Karen will refuse the company and assistance of any of her friends. Each of them will find themselves having to confront plenty of their own problems anyway.
Tyler Perry’s “Sistas” has become a staple of BET programming, and even has its own spinoff, “Divorced Sistas.” The series follows a group of women and their friends as they attempt to navigate love, relationships, their careers, and more in the face of the modern world’s modern challenges (such as social media).
If you’re not satisfied with some of the options above, another way to watch “Sistas” is Sling, and while it doesn’t offer a free trial, you can sign up for half price for the first month. It also offers an easy way to sign up for BET+, which features every episode of “Sistas” on demand.
The series stars KJ Smith as Andrea “Andi” Barnes, Ebony Obsidian as Karen Mott, Mignon Von as Daniella “Danni” King, Novi Brown as Sabrina Hollins, Chido Nwokocha as Gary Marshall Borders, DeVale Ellis as Zac Taylor, and Brian Jordan Jr. as Maurice Webb, among tons of others.
Here’s a look at the promo for last week’s episode of “Sistas,” courtesy of the US News Box Official YouTube channel:
When is Tyler Perry’s ‘Sistas’ on?
The third episode of Tyler Perry’s “Sistas” will be led into by a rerun of the movie “Creed III,” and will kick off at 9 p.m. It will also be followed by a new episode of “The Family Business: New Orleans” at 10 p.m.
How to watch Tyler Perry’s ‘Sistas’ online on-demand
If you want to record Tyler Perry’s “Sistas” or you just want to watch other BET content online as it becomes available, check out Philo (free trial) or DirecTV (free trial) or Fubo TV (free trial).
Sling TV is also half off your first month, and offers a ton of customization.
Philo is the best option for something sleek, cheap, and fast, while DirecTV or Fubo TV are better for long-term cord cutters.
If you’re not in the US, you can still use a VPN to sign up for any one of these services and set your location to a US server.
Among the safest choices to use are ExpressVPN or NordVPN. Both services offer massive discounts, along with a 100% money-back guarantee within the first 30 days.
More to watch on Sling TV

Joseph Rejent covers TV, writing about live television, streaming services and cord-cutting. He can be reached at jrejent@njadvancemedia.com.

HBO Max’s password-sharing crackdown is about to get stricter. During an earnings call on Thursday, Warner Bros. Discovery streaming head JB Perette said prompts surrounding account sharing will become more persistent starting next month, pushing people toward paying an extra $7.99 per month to add an extra member to their account.
“In September, you’ll actually start to see the messaging — which right now has been a fairly soft, cancelable messaging — start to get more fixed and such that people have to take action,” Perette said, adding that right now, paid sharing is “a voluntary process.”
Following password-sharing crackdowns at Netflix and Disney Plus, Warner Bros. Discovery announced its own plan to introduce paid sharing last year. So far, HBO Max has introduced “soft messaging” surrounding the change, but it hasn’t begun to strictly enforce the policy.
The streamer added 3.4 million subscribers in the months following its debrand from Max to HBO Max, and it will begin driving paid sharing “in a much more aggressive fashion” later this year, according to Perette. HBO Max currently uses account information, IP addresses, device IDs, and user activity to determine if someone is sharing their account with a person outside their household.
Warner Bros. Discovery execs expect paid sharing to boost subscriber growth, which Netflix reported following its clampdown. But as subscription fatigue continues to grow, making people pay to share their passwords might not go over smoothly with subscribers.

Netflix is about to kick your best friend off your account — unless you pay for them to share your account, that is. On Tuesday, Netflix revealed the details of how its crackdown on password sharing will affect viewers in the US and how much it will cost to keep extra people on your account.
If you have the Netflix Standard plan that costs $15.49 per month, then you have the option of adding one extra member who can use the service outside your household for $7.99 extra each month. Anyone who pays for the Netflix Premium package with 4K streaming has the option of adding up to two extra members, but each one will still cost another $7.99. The US isn’t the only country where the new rules are rolling out either, as Netflix in the UK will charge subscribers £4.99 each month for extra member slots.
Netflix subscribers on its two cheapest plans (Basic or Standard with Ads, which cost $9.99 and $6.99 per month, respectively) don’t have the option to add extra members to their account at all.
Netflix subscribers in the US who share the service “outside their household” will get an email about the company’s password-sharing policies beginning on Tuesday, according to the blog post.
Netflix’s paid password-sharing experiments have been happening for a while, and it expanded its tests to Canada, New Zealand, Portugal, and Spain in February. The password-sharing crackdown was originally supposed to hit the US at the beginning of this year, but the company pushed that launch back again in April.
A support page explaining the new setup describes “extra members” as someone who will have their own password and profile, paid for by the person who “invited” them to join. Extra member accounts also have their own set of restrictions. They have to be activated in the same country, they can only view or download content on one device at a time, and they can’t create extra profiles or log in as a Kids profile.
Your Netflix household, according to the company, is set based on where you watch Netflix on a TV and what IP address that device uses. That location can be reset using the app on a TV or a device connected to a TV by choosing to confirm or update your household and responding to a verification link sent to the account’s listed email address or phone number.
We use information such as IP addresses, device IDs, and account activity to determine whether a device signed into your account is part of your Netflix Household.
We do not collect GPS data to try to determine the precise physical location of your devices.
If a Netflix Household hasn’t been set, we will automatically set one for you based on IP address, device IDs, and account activity.
You can always update your Netflix Household from a TV by connecting to your internet and following the steps above.
Netflix used to be very pro-password sharing — in March 2017, it famously tweeted, “Love is sharing a password.” (That tweet, as of this writing, is still up.) But in early 2022, it started testing ways to end the practice and get people to pay for accounts using Netflix outside of the account owner’s household.
In April 2022, the company revealed that it lost subscribers for the first time in over a decade, and it said at the time that more than 100 million households were getting Netflix through password sharing.
As it’s tried to turn that subscriber growth around, cracking down on password sharing is just one of many levers the company has pulled. It also introduced an ads plan, which has nearly 5 million global active users and has invested heavily in games as an extra perk for subscribers.
Update May 23rd, 7:24PM ET: Added UK pricing.
Disclosure: The Verge recently produced a series with Netflix.

If you’ve been sharing account access to HBO Max, the good times are soon coming to an end.
JB Perrette, head of streaming and gaming at Warner Bros. Discovery said on the company’s second-quarter earnings call that messaging to consumers is about to get more “aggressive.” The media company looking to close the loopholes by the end of 2025, with the impact starting to appear in its financials by 2026.
Following in Netflix’s lead, WBD, Disney and other media companies are all ramping up efforts to limit password sharing, anticipating a significant financial payoff from cracking down on once-overlooked practice.
Several months of testing has enabled WBD to determine “who’s a legitimate user who may not be a legitimate user,” Perrette said. Once that is determined, he continued, the next step is to “turn on the more aggressive language around what needs to happen” in order to and make sure that “we are putting the net in the right place, so to speak.”
Watch on Deadline
Asked about what “inning” the process is in, to use the baseball cliché, Perrette said only the first. By the fourth quarter, he said, the process will be happening “in a much more aggressive fashion.”
“The message language right now has been a fairly soft, cancel-able message,” he said. It will “start to get more fixed and such that people have to take action as opposed to right now, sort of having to be a voluntary process.” Once those directives are established, he said, “the real benefit will start probably in the fourth quarter and then kick in in 2026.”
WBD reported solid results for the quarter, adding 3.4 million streaming subscribers (mostly via international expansion) to reach 125.7 million overall.
Greedy. Lame. Ridiculous. ‘Murica.
So you’re saying cancel my account since they want to be greedy? Copy that
Oh hey, there goes the one subscription I thought was worth keeping. Once it takes affect I’ll cancel after 7 years
Love how a “feature” (Share with Family and Friends) turns into a “problem” (Thieves stealing content) when the market gets saturated.
It’s a shame they don’t spend as much time on their content as they do trying to figure out how to screw their own customers.
Not customers. Thiefs.

First Paramount Plus dropped them. Now, after the season 27 premiere, HBO Max has kicked “South Park” to the curb, too.
Except that’s not exactly what happened. While at one point, Paramount Plus had removed “South Park” from its streaming lineup, leaving only the specials, the series is now available, in full, on their service. All 392 episodes are right there, available in just a few clicks.
Creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone signed a $1.5 billion deal to continue the series on Comedy Central, and now that the negotiations have resolved, the best place to watch the series is once again on Paramount Plus, its official home.
However, the same deal that brought the show back to one service was its death knell on another. As of Aug. 5, HBO Max has pulled all 26 seasons of the beloved, controversial comedy from its roster. That means you can no longer find any “South Park” content on HBO Max.
If you’re interested in watching, you will have to sign up for another service.
The good news is that there is a lot of flexibility in the other options that are available to you. As we’ve mentioned, the first 26 seasons of the series are available on Paramount Plus. This is also a great place to watch the season 27 premiere, and future episodes the day after they release.
However, if you’re looking to watch Comedy Central live, so you don’t miss new episodes the second they premiere, you can also sign up for a free trial of Philo, DirecTV, or Fubo TV (free trial), or you can get 1/2 off your first month of Sling TV. There are still plenty of options available to you.
The next episode of “South Park” season 27 releases on Wednesday, Aug. 6 at 10 p.m.

After 17 long years, Hulu is riding off into the sunset.
It won’t disappear completely, however. This is more a story of change than of death.
In their quarterly earnings call, Disney CEO Bob Iger announced that the company would be "fully integrating Hulu into Disney+," with the purpose to “create an impressive package of entertainment, pairing the highest-caliber brands and franchises, great general entertainment, family programming, news, and industry-leading live sports content in a single app.”
In other words, Hulu, which is owned entirely by Disney, will become a part of Disney+. The two will no longer serve as sister services with overlapping content. Part of the company’s plan involves replacing the Star Wars franchise tab in the Disney+ app with the Hulu logo, making it the new official home of Hulu-branded content.
A new version of the Disney+ and Hulu streaming app will make its debut in 2026. The company also maintains that consumers will still be able to purchase an individual subscription to either Hulu or to Disney+. At this time, it is unclear how exactly that will work, or whether Hulu will remain a standalone app in any form.
Hulu is the official home of countless acclaimed series, ranging from recent Emmys juggernaut “The Bear” to the upcoming “Alien: Earth,” a series set in the “Alien” universe from “Fargo” creator Noah Hawley.

“South Park” has survived a second round of uncertainty around the second episode of season 27. True to form, the show immediately did its best to stir up a new controversy.
Once again, we won’t spoil it here, but the new episode is less likely to be controversial for its depiction of President Donald Trump than for the way it poked fun at Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem.
You can watch all of season 27 so far on its official home on Paramount+ (free trial), where the series is once again available, or by signing up for a free trial of Philo, DirecTV, or Fubo TV (free trial), or you can get 1/2 off your first month of Sling TV.
The episode was titled “Got a Nut,” and it turned the series ruthless sense of humor on Vice President J.D. Vance and Charlie Kirk, as well.
Trey Parker and Matt Stone created “South Park” in 1997 on a shoestring budget, and though the animation techniques they used have evolved, it still retains the look of its original cutout animation. Parker and Stone are also the show’s lead writers, and they voice most of the show’s iconic characters, which include Stan Marsh, Kyle Broflovski, Kenny McCormick, and Eric Cartman.
How to watch ‘South Park’ online on-demand
The confusion surrounding where to stream “South Park” seems to have abated. As of the premiere of season 27 airing on July 23, the show has returned to Paramount Plus, where it is available to stream in its entirety. The free trial for the service lasts 7 days.
However, if you want to watch future episodes of the series live as they air, there are other options available to you, as well. Philo is a quick, easy way to watch the series, and it’s cheaper than most of its competitors after the 7-day free trial. Other choices, with a more expansive channel selection, include DirecTV or Fubo TV or Sling TV.
More to watch on Sling TV

“South Park” has always been a little chaotic, but that seems to be doubly true these days.
After a dramatic contract showdown, the show being removed from Paramount Plus and then added again, then being removed from HBO Max, and now two separate delays, “South Park” is airing the second episode of season 27 on Comedy Central on Wednesday, Aug. 6 at 10 p.m.
You can watch live as it premieres on Philo (free trial) or DirecTV (free trial) or Fubo TV (free trial) or Sling TV (half off first month).
It appears that the episode will be entitled “Got a Nut,” and that it will mostly revolve around Mr. Mackey losing his job and possibly joining ICE, the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency.
“South Park” is one of the longest-running animated comedies in television history. The story follows 4th graders Cartman, Kyle, Stan, and Kenny as they get into various extreme hijinks around the small, titular Colorado town they live in. Most of the show’s iconic cast of characters are voiced by Trey Parker and Matt Stone, the creators and writers of the series, themselves.
Here’s a look at the teaser for episode 2 of season 27, courtesy of the show’s official YouTube channel:
When is ‘South Park’ actually on?
After all its delays and confusion, the latest episode of “South Park” will premiere at 10 p.m. on Wednesday, Aug. 6. It will lead into a new episode of “Digman!” at 10:30 p.m.
How to watch ‘South Park’ online on-demand
Paramount Plus is the official streaming home of “South Park,” where all of the series is currently available to stream, along with its many specials and movies. It also releases the latest episodes of the series around 12 hours after they air.
If you’re looking to watch the episode live as it airs, we suggest Philo, which is fast, sleek, and easy to use.
More to watch on Sling TV

argos_summary: HBO Max is intensifying its crackdown on password sharing, with plans to implement stricter measures starting next month. Users sharing accounts outside their households will be prompted to pay an additional $7.99 per month for extra members. This move follows similar actions by Netflix and Disney Plus, as streaming services seek to boost subscriber growth amid increasing competition and subscription fatigue.
